item.title: Safety hazard: Failure to reinstate double yellow lines on narrow bus route following resurfacing., 21st January
item.description:
During the resurfacing of Alsike Road (Jan 12–14), the contractors failed to repaint the double yellow lines on the narrowest section of the road. Because the opposite side allows free parking, cars are now parking on both sides of the street. This has created a dangerous bottleneck that prevents buses and emergency vehicles from passing through. The lines need to be reinstated immediately to prevent the road from being completely blocked and to maintain the safety of the bus route.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Alsike Road, West Heath, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: In the road on Bidborough near Cartwright Gardens, 21st January
item.description:
Large/long concrete sleeper/cobble is protruding up a couple of inches out of the road, it’s a hazard for cyclists and pedestrians as it’s not easily seen
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Gray's Inn Road, Holborn, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Inadequate road camber and drainage failure following recent resurfacing., 21st January
item.description:
Following the road resurfacing between January 12th and 14th, the tarmac has been finished with an incorrect curve (camber). Instead of water flowing into the drains, it is pooling into a large, deep flood directly outside my property (Alsike Road). This makes it impossible to access or exit a vehicle parked here without wading through deep water. The road was not leveled correctly by the contractors, and the standing water now poses a long-term risk to the road surface and property access.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Alsike Road, West Heath, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Builders rubble in overflowing black bags, 21st January
item.description:

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Unit 247, 248, Pelier Street, Walworth, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Recurring pothole in road, 21st January
item.description:
You referred to this as repaired reference 8706736. I pointed out to you at the time that this pothole probably has no foundation under it. At one point a hole was dug at this location to repair electrics. Ever since and due to the constant bus convoys it is subjected to thrusts the tarmac down and out. You can see from this repair that is already happening. This time repair it properly. Otherwise we may find that like the very large pothole in the middle of The Park road, buses will be disappearing down it. That pothole was I suspect due to the lengthy gas repair works in this vicinity going through the road foundation. The heaviest vehicle in The Park is the refuse lorry.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 5, Elm Road, Longlands, Sidcup, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Huge amount of household waste dumped on industrial yard, 21st January
item.description:
We saw a group of men in a van dumping household waste in the yard to the North of the Lordship North estate at night - around 11pm. They must have done a few loads as it went from empty to full of rubbish in a day or two. It's right next to the reservoir.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Lordship Road, Hackney, London
Report on FixMyStreet

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Gordon Road, Northumberland Heath, Greater London
